snippet: Calls for international prosecution, legal experts say, are likely to grow so long as the United States chooses not to prosecute its own.
abstract: Legal analysts say that Americans who order or carry out torture can be prosecuted abroad, by legal bodies including International Criminal Court; experts question whether such prosecutions will happen, but predict that calls for punishment will grow as long as United States declines to prosecute it own citizens.

byline.contributor: Joanna Berendt contributed reporting from Warsaw, and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: Calls for international prosecution, legal experts say, are likely to grow so long as the United States chooses not to prosecute its own.

headline.main: Americans Involved in Torture Can Be Prosecuted Abroad, Analysts Say
headline.print_headline: Americans Involved in Torture Can Be Prosecuted Abroad, Analysts Say

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
